title: Zachary Dickson
text:
I’m currently a PhD candidate in politics at the  University of 
Glasgow and will be joining the  COVIDEU project as a postdoctoral researcher at the  London School of Economics and Political Science in the fall (2022). In my research, I use computational methods and social data to study legislative behavior. I'm especially interested in legislators' communication and responsiveness to public opinion in liberal democracies. 


In my PhD thesis, I explore the ways in which representatives' social identity enables unequal responsiveness to different groups within the electorate. The thesis consists of four separate articles that focus on characteristics such as gender, social class, and educational background, and the extent to which these experiences influence representation and responsiveness in the US and UK. For a deeper look at my doctoral research, which is supervised by  Sergiu Gherghina  and  Sergi Pardos-Prado, feel free to download a extended abstract  here. 




Prior to my current doctoral research at the University of Glasgow, I earned my masters in international relations at the University of Edinburgh and my bachelor’s degree in political science at Northeastern Illinois University in my hometown of Chicago.


A (somewhat) current version of my CV can be downloaded  here.

title: about
text:
My PhD thesis is a collection of four essays that explore the tension between elites’ socialization and self-interest and the ways in which the two influence legislative responsiveness to public opinion. The thesis broadly focuses on explanations for differential responsiveness to public opinion by examining the socialization factors underlying descriptive representation such as gender and class. I argue and demonstrate that these factors play a fundamental roles in shaping legislative behavior; yet, self-interest motivations account for substantial variation in legislative responsiveness to the public. For a deeper look at my doctoral research, which is supervised by  Sergiu Gherghina  and  Sergi Pardos-Prado, feel free to to download a extended abstract  here. 
Prior to my current doctoral research at the University of Glasgow, I earned my masters in international relations at the University of Edinburgh and my bachelor’s degree in political science at Northeastern Illinois University in my hometown of Chicago.
